Rust has several primitive data types and a powerful type system.
Rust has four primary scalar types:
• Integers: i8, i16, i32, i64, i128, isize, u8, u16, u32, u64, u128, usize
• Floating-point: f32, f64
• Boolean: bool
• Character: char

Rust has two primitive compound types: tuples and arrays.
Tuples: A tuple is a collection of values of different types.
Arrays: An array is a collection of values of the same type with fixed length.
Ownership is Rust's most unique feature, enabling memory safety without a garbage collector.
Rust's ownership system has three main rules:
1. Each value in Rust has a variable that's called its owner.
2. There can only be one owner at a time.
3. When the owner goes out of scope, the value will be dropped.

The & symbol creates a reference that allows you to refer to the value without taking ownership.
